 I think you are wrong in forcing a woman to keep her pregnancy in the first and second trimester since I, and pretty much all others on the pro-choice side, place a lot of value in a person's right to their own body and forcing a pregnancy to term is a violation of that right of the mother to her own body. If it were only a question of the woman's right to her body and no other rights of any other person existed regarding her pregnancy, then the issue would be clear cut for her entire pregnancy. However, the question on both sides of the debate is "When does the FETUS acquire rights?". Though people on the pro-choice side differ in their views (ex. some say that the fetus does not acquire rights until birth), apparently most would severely restrict third trimester abortions - suggesting that most pro-choice advocates start taking the fetus's rights into account at that point (third trimester). I myself find mental existence to be the critical development (be it even a rudimentary sense of self, rudimentary thoughts or emotions, or a sense of registered pain - as apposed to mere reflex action). Science tells us that this cannot develop until around the start of the third trimester, when sufficient connections develop in the cerebral cortex of the brain. Before the fetus develops a rudimentary mental existence, it is just a body with "nobody home" which, in my view, does not get rights. I did not exist as a person until I started to do so mentally. If I had been aborted prior to that time, nobody would have been hurt. The same goes for any fetus. After that mental existence starts, then there is a balance of the rights of the fetus to life vs the rights of the mother to her own body (or any other rights that come in, such as her right to self-protection if that fetus's life is risking hers). In general then, I would leave abortion completely free in the first and second trimesters and restrict it to a few exceptions in the third trimester (including risk to mother's life, severe risk to her health, mercy killing and possibly rape, incest).
 
 So, what is your justification for forcing a woman to continue her pregnancy in all trimesters?

 As I said before, once the unborn develops enough so that it CAN have mental existence, I give it rights. I do not give it rights BEFORE it can have mental existence. Therefore, it gets no rights in the first and second trimester and I would allow unrestricted abortions then. Yes, if left to grow, an embryo will most likely develop mental existence but that is in its future, not in its present - meaning that it has the POTENTIAL to have that mental existence but does not have it NOW. It is its current state which I judge in determining if it has rights - not its future state. After all, a pre-fertilized egg also has the potential to become a full person if a few things happen (including fertilization). I judge the living entity in question by what it is *at that moment*.
 
 If you do not understand that point, I will put it another way. There are three states of knowledge about the fetus's mental existence:
 1) Prior to roughly the beginning of the third trimester, it CANNOT have mental existence (as supported by evidence of neurologists). Therefore, I do not give it rights.
 2) At some point, there is concrete evidence of mental existence - perhaps once it first gains consciousness. It clearly has rights for me at that stage.
 3) There is a period of time from around the beginning of the third trimester to the point where we definitely know it has mental existence. During this time, we just don't know either way if it has mental existence. One can either err on the side of caution (as I do) and say that, since it CAN have mental existence during this time, give the fetus rights. This runs the smallest risk (indeed zero risk) of unjustly aborting a fetus that might actually have mental existence at that moment. Otherwise, one can err on the side of certainty and not grant the fetus rights until mental existence is proven. That runs a fairly big risk of unjustly aborting a fetus that might have mental existence at that moment - which is why I prefer to err on the side of caution instead.

Well belief or not in the question of abortion is not an easy matter.

 Virtually every argument religious or otherwise can have an equal counter-argument.
 
 Ultimately it may depend on the circumstances of the individual at the time.
 
 Rape, sickness, inability to cope, deformation in the embryo, all play their part. And again will be different for each individual.

 Again personally I believe it to be too easy and I definitely believe that it should not occur late in a pregnancy without strong medical grounds.
 
 Judge each case on its merits.

Alright, time for me to weigh in on the Abortion forums. I am personally Pro-choice. By this, I mean I support a woman's right to control the use of her body, whether she wants to get an abortion or not. From what I've seen of Jitobear, my thoughts are close to hers. I am NOT pro-abortion, in fact I do not like how it is used in many cases, but banning it is NOT the answer. We need to look at the underlying causes of abortion, and thus the underlying causes of unwanted pregnancy, and we need to work to fix THOSE problems if we want abortion rates to fall. I support women's choice whether it is to continue or end her pregnancy.
 
 As far as the foetus, I see it as a recognizable living organism, but NOT as a human, and NOT as a moral equal to living humans. As a pesco-lacto-vegetarian (a vegetarian who eats fish and drinks milk besides the whole vegetarian part as long as the animals used for the milk are treated ethically - I also have no moral problem with the consumption of eggs, but I just happen to not like the taste), I view the foetus on a similar moral level as that of fish (except without the desire to eat them :) ). That is, just as I do not view most fish as sentient, the same goes for foetuses, so they are at a much lower moral level than other animals (cows, dogs, chickens, etc.) including existing humans.
 
 Well, I've rambled on enough - those are my views on this issue.
